raw_text:
Labour's four little words
 
 Labour has unveiled the four little words that will form the heart of its general election campaign which, for those just returned from the planet Galifray, is "looming".
 
 The slogan "Britain forward not back" (no, it's not an instruction from one of those inter-planetary Time Lords) is to become as much a part of our daily lives as the sky - it's always there but we mostly stop noticing. The word "Britain" is cast on a red background - a nod to Old Labour. "Forward" is in italics and cunningly slopes forward and, along with "not back", is set against a mushy pea green background. As one of the journalists assembled at the unveiling declared, it was all very post modern, or something. Great use of colour. Those ad men really do earn their money. And, coincidentally, the ad men who came up with the abandoned flying pigs and so-called "Fagin" posters which caused Tory protests have not been sacked but, as election supremo Alan Milburn declared, "are doing a very good job".
 
 Mr Milburn, in the latest in his series of pre-election-campaign campaigning, explained the slogan was the reaction to polling which suggests the public believe Labour and Tony Blair are the future while Michael Howard and the Tories would take the country backwards. "Not many people talk about the years before 1997 as the good old days," he declared. It would be an aggressive campaign because things would inevitably boil down to a choice between Labour and the Tories.
 
 Nobody, he claimed, could picture Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy walking up Downing Street the day after polling. They could, however, picture Michael Howard or, of course, Tony Blair doing it. So it was only right that the campaign concentrated on rigorously examining the opposition's policies and past record. And Tony Blair would be in the very front line of that campaign, he said. "Between now and the election the prime minister will be spending more time out of London than in it but in Britain, not overseas," he promised. "He will be leading the domestic debate from the front, listening, taking the flak." So, let's get on with it then.
llama3.2:1b: Labour's general election slogan is "Britain forward not back" which features the words "looming".
The word "Britain" is set on a red background and the phrase is in both bold and italic font.
A green background with sloping text suggests a postmodern design style.
The slogan is intended to become part of daily life, similar to how the sky exists but is mostly unnoticed.
llama3.2:3b: Labour has unveiled its general election campaign slogan "Britain forward not back" with a red background for "Britain", a mushy pea green background for "forward" and "not back".
The slogan reflects polling that suggests the public believes Labour is the future, while the Tories would take the country backwards.
gemma2:2b: Labour's general election campaign slogan is "Britain forward not back".
The campaign will focus on examining the Tory party's policies and record, and Tony Blair will be central to this.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The Labour party is launching a general election campaign which promises to be a significant moment for voters as the slogan "Britain forward not back" becomes increasingly important.
The slogan is cast in red and written in italic style, along with an image of a flying pig and a green background.
It's all about highlighting a contrast between the public perception of Labour and Tony Blair's leadership.
Labour aims to focus their campaign on examining the opposition's policies and past record, with Michael Howard at the forefront of this effort.
The campaign promises to be fierce and aggressive in their efforts against the Conservatives, who are seen as "the future" while Labour is portrayed as an alternative.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Labour has unveiled a campaign slogan featuring four simple words: "Britain forward, not back."
The ad employs modern design elements to emphasize its message of change and progress.
qwen2.5:3b: Labour’s campaign slogan is “Britain forward not back,” incorporating modern design elements like a red background for "Britain" and an italicized "forward" set against green, symbolizing progress.
The slogan was developed in response to polling indicating the public views Labour as the future while the Tories are seen as taking the country backwards.
Labour plans an aggressive campaign focusing on scrutinizing the opposition’s policies, with Blair expected to be at the forefront of the domestic debate leading up to the election.
opencoder:1.5b: Labour's four little words are a summary of the provided text, preserving key ideas and details.

The introduction talks about Labour's vision for a future where forward motion is commonplace in our daily lives while not back doesn't come up in the discussion because it's not an instruction from one of those Time Lords.
The main focus on examining past records, public opinion, and a potential strategy for election supremacy.
smollm:1.7b: The Labour Party has unveiled four little words that will form its general election campaign: "looming".
The slogan is to become as much a part of our daily lives as the sky and we mostly stop noticing.
The word "Britain" is cast on a red background - a nod to Old Labour.
"Forward" is in italics and cunningly slopes forward and, along with "not back", is set against a mushy pea green background.
As one of the journalists assembled at the unveiling declared, it was all very post modern, or something.
Those ad men really do earn their money.

And, coincidentally, the ad men who came up with the abandoned flying pigs and so-called "Fagin" posters which caused Tory protests have not been sacked but, as election supremo Alan Milburn declared, they are doing a very good job.
Nobody, he claimed, could picture Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy walking up Downing Street the day after polling.
They could, however, picture Michael Howard or, of course, Tony Blair doing it.
So it was only right that the campaign concentrated on rigorously examining the opposition's policies and past record.
And Tony Blair would be in the very front line of that campaign, he said.
"Between now and the election the prime minister will be spending more time out of London than in it but in Britain, not overseas," he promised.
"He will be leading the domestic debate from the front, listening, taking the flak."
So, let's get on with it then.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Labour's four little words "Britain forward not back" will form the heart of their general election campaign.
The slogan is embedded daily life, often overlooked, especially for those returning from Galifray.
Poll data suggests public belief in Labour ahead, with the Tories behind, as pollsters like Tony Blair opposed.
Labour's focus is on evaluating opposition policies and conducting domestic debates from the front, spending more time in London than overseas.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Labour party has unveiled a campaign slogan that will become an integral part of daily life, and it's titled "Brithain forward not back" (no, it's not an instruction from the Time Lord).
The word "Brithain" is cast in a red background and slants forward as if to say, "forward" while the rest of the slogan, "not back," is set against a pea green background.
It was all very postmodern, or something.
The ad men who created the infamous "Faigin" and "faino" campaigns are doing quite well for themselves.

Labour's prime ministerial candidate, Tony Blair, will be focusing on domestic issues in his bid to lead the country into the next phase of British history, a slogan that was introduced by Alan Milburn during a pre-election campaigning stroll.
The "Brithain" campaign has been designed to emphasize the party's strong commitment to the nation while not forgetting its past mistakes and achievements.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Labour has announced a slogan for their upcoming general election campaign that uses four little words to convey their message: "Britain forward not back".
The campaign has been designed to become as much a part of our daily lives as the sky, using the word "Britain" against a background mushy pea green.
They have also chosen to refer to themselves as the "Forward Britain" party, which is reminiscent of their previous choice of "Go forward, Britain!
phi:2.7b: Labour has unveiled the slogan "Britain forward not back", which aims to counter public perceptions that they are the future while the Tories and Michael Howard would take the country backwards.
The campaign will be aggressive, examining the opposition's policies and past record, and Tony Blair will lead the domestic debate.
orca-mini:3b: The Labour party has unveiled a slogan that will form its general election campaign, which focuses on the idea that Britain should move forward rather than go back to the past.
The slogan "Britain forward not back" uses bold and green colors on a red background.
The slogan is inspired by postmodern art and design and emphasizes the importance of progress.

The party's leader Alan Milburn stated that the slogan was created in response to recent polls that suggest the public believes Labour and Tony Blair are the future while Michael Howard and the Tories would take the country backwards.
The campaign will focus on examining the opposition's policies and past record, with Tony Blair leading the domestic debate from the front.
hermes3:3b: Labour presents campaign slogan "Britain forward not back" to counter perception of going backward compared to Tories.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Labour has unveiled its general election campaign slogan: "Britain forward not back", with the aim of emphasizing their policies and stance against Michael Howard's Tories.
The slogan is a reaction to polling data suggesting the public believes Labour and Tony Blair are the future, while the Tories would take the country backwards.
The campaign will focus on examining the opposition's policies and past record, with Prime Minister Tony Blair leading the domestic debate from the front.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Labour has launched its general election campaign slogan, "Britain forward not back," designed to emphasize progress under Tony Blair while portraying the Conservatives as a step backward.
The slogan's design includes a red background for "Britain" as a nod to Old Labour and a forward-slanting "Forward" in italics.
Election chief Alan Milburn stated the campaign would be aggressive, focusing on contrasting Labour’s future vision with the Tories' past record.
He dismissed the Liberal Democrats as unlikely contenders and emphasized Blair’s active role in the campaign, promising he would engage directly with voters across the country.
stablelm2:1.6b: Labour has announced their campaign slogan for the general election: "Britain forward not back".
The phrase emphasizes Labour's belief that they represent progress and moving the country forward while opposing parties like Michael Howard and the Tories go back.
This is in contrast to a post-modern design featuring the word "Britain" on a red background and "Forward" in italics with a green backdrop, which symbolizes the modern era.
Alan Milburn, the election strategist, explains that this slogan reflects recent polling results indicating public approval of Labour's leadership and policies compared to Michael Howard's approach.
The campaign will focus on scrutinizing Tory and Liberal Democrat opposition platforms.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Labour has introduced a new campaign slogan, "Britain forward not back", to emphasize its stance as the party of progress and continuity over Tory backwardness.
The slogan features bold, contrasting colors: "Britain" in red against a mushy pea green background, and "not back" in italics sloping forward.
This design is a deliberate nod to Labour's roots and modern campaign strategy.
The slogan was developed based on polling data indicating public preference for Labour and Tony Blair as the future, while viewing Michael Howard and the Conservatives as a step back.

The campaign will be aggressive, focusing on scrutinizing the opposition's policies and past records, with an emphasis on Prime Minister Tony Blair leading the domestic debate from Britain rather than abroad.
Charles Kennedy, Liberal Democrat leader, is not expected to become Prime Minister.
